pullRequest.body:
This constructs a norm on the `Unitization ùïú A` of a (possibly non-unital) normed algebra `A`, subject to the condition that `ContinuousLinearMap.mul ùïú A` is an isometry. A norm on `A` satisfying this property is said to be regular so we add the class `RegularNormedAlgebra` where this construction makes sense.

This norm is particularly nice because, among norms on the unitization of a `RegularNormedAlgebra`, this norm is minimal. Moreover, it is the (necessarily unique) C‚ãÜ-norm on the unitization when the norm on `A` is a C‚ãÜ-norm (see #5393)

- [x] depends on: #5741

---

I'm open to making this a scoped instance, but I think this is the norm we will want most often. The norm arising from `PiLp 1` is another possibility, and would be available in greater generality (no need for `RegularNormedAlgebra`), but I think if we want that we should perhaps use a type synonym.

One other note: I have removed the `after-port` tag because I feel the changes to existing material are minimal enough and used in few enough places, but if anyone feels differently they can add it back. The real changes to existing material occur in `Analysis.NormedSpace.OperatorNorm`.

Thanks, and sorry for the slow review!

bors d+

Thanks, and sorry for the slow review!

bors d+
This comes in a later PR, right? I think it's fine to leave the comment as is, just wanted to check.
Yes, it's in #5393
Is this terminology standard? I had in mind that the left regular representation of an algebra was just the multiplication on itself, but maybe that is only satisfying for unital algebras.
No, it's not standard. I'm open to other names, especially because the current name doesn't take the first coordinate into account either. Maybe `liftLeftRegRep`?

What do you think of `splitMul`? Because it's exactly the multiplication by an element of `Unitization ùïú A`, but splitted as an action on `ùïú` and an action on `A`.

Another option, as suggested by [this answer on MO](https://mathoverflow.net/a/210217), is to actually consider the mutliplication as a map `Unitization ùïú A ‚Üí‚Çê[ùïú] (ùïú √ó A) ‚ÜíL[ùïú] (ùïú √ó A)`, which should give the same norm from what I understand. But that may be a bit more work, and I'm not sure how useful that is.

@ADedecker `splitMul` is fine. However, as for the answer on MO, I believe my construction is nicer. In the MO version, you must first bundle the function `fun a ‚Ü¶ (0 : ùïú ‚ÜíL[ùïú] ùïú).prodMap (ContinuousLinearMap.mul ùïú A a)` from `A` to `(ùïú √ó A) ‚ÜíL[ùïú] (ùïú √ó A)` into a non-unital algebra homomorphism, called `foo ùïú A`, then the algebra homomorphism described on MO is `Unitization.lift (foo ùïú A)`. I really don't think this any better, and in fact, I think it would be significantly harder to work with. And just to be clear, it's not like the MO construction avoids the need for `ContinuousLinearMap.mul ùïú A` to be injective, that is still necessary to ensure injectivity of this algebra homomorphism (as should be clear from the above).
I understand my mistake: I thought that `foo ùïú A` was exactly mutiplication in the unitization (which is clearly injective), but there's a term missing. So indeed this doesn't simplify anything.

Do you actually care about the constants here? If not I have a proposition that looks cleaner in my opinion and avoid the constants. It would start like this:
```lean
open Filter Topology

/-- The identity map between `Unitization ùïú A` and `ùïú √ó A` as an `AddEquiv`. -/
protected def linearEquiv : Unitization ùïú A ‚âÉ‚Çó[ùïú] ùïú √ó A :=
  LinearEquiv.refl _ _

/-- The uniformity on `Unitization ùïú A` is inherited from `ùïú √ó A`. -/
instance instUniformSpace : UniformSpace (Unitization ùïú A) :=
  instUniformSpaceProd.comap Unitization.linearEquiv

instance : UniformAddGroup (Unitization ùïú A) :=
  uniformAddGroup_comap _

instance : ContinuousSMul ùïú (Unitization ùïú A) :=
  continuousSMul_induced _

protected lemma uniformInducing_linearEquiv :
    UniformInducing (Unitization.linearEquiv : Unitization ùïú A ‚âÉ‚Çó[ùïú] ùïú √ó A) :=
  ‚ü®rfl‚ü©

-- this may be a bad idea: this is a technical definition, it should not pollute the simp set
@[simps]
protected def shearRight : (ùïú √ó (A ‚ÜíL[ùïú] A)) ‚âÉ·µ§ (ùïú √ó (A ‚ÜíL[ùïú] A)) where
  toFun := fun (k, T) ‚Ü¶ (k, algebraMap ùïú (A ‚ÜíL[ùïú] A) k + T)
  invFun := fun (k, T) ‚Ü¶ (k, T - algebraMap ùïú (A ‚ÜíL[ùïú] A) k)
  left_inv := fun (k, T) ‚Ü¶ by simp only [add_sub_cancel']
  right_inv := fun (k, T) ‚Ü¶ by simp only [add_sub_cancel'_right]
  uniformContinuous_toFun := uniformContinuous_fst.prod_mk <|
    ((algebraMapClm ùïú (A ‚ÜíL[ùïú] A)).uniformContinuous.comp uniformContinuous_fst).add
    uniformContinuous_snd
  uniformContinuous_invFun := uniformContinuous_fst.prod_mk <| uniformContinuous_snd.sub
    ((algebraMapClm ùïú (A ‚ÜíL[ùïú] A)).uniformContinuous.comp uniformContinuous_fst)

protected theorem uniformInducing_splitMul : UniformInducing (splitMul ùïú A) := by
  convert Unitization.shearRight.uniformInducing.comp <|
    (uniformInducing_id.prod (isometry_mul ùïú A).uniformEmbedding.toUniformInducing).comp
    Unitization.uniformInducing_linearEquiv
  ext <;>
  simp <;> rfl
```
That should give you almost immediately that the topology and uniformity are what you want, and only the bornology remains. But then you can use [ContinuousLinearMap.antilipschitz_of_embedding](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/NormedSpace/OperatorNorm.html#ContinuousLinearMap.antilipschitz_of_embedding) to get [anti]lipshcitzness (but with unknown constants) so you can get the bornology equality.

The nice thing is that it avoids declaring any local instance, and *in my opinion*it's nicer to avoid the computations *in my opinion* (I know Moritz for example doesn't agree at all...).

After some offline discussion, we came to the conclusion that this approach doesn't really avoid the need for the local instances because the argument that the bornologies coincide still uses the metric structure.

The statements of these two lemmas mention the temporary instances, which could get a bit annoying. Two solutions I see are (1) add `'` to these ones and restate them correctly at the end of the file (2) declare the norm as a (non-temporary) instance of `Norm` from the beginning.

EDIT: I see that they seem to work fine for rewriting, but I don't understand why :sweat_smile:
since it seems to behave, are you okay if we leave it as is?
I'm not sure how much you want to defeq-abuse here, but I would be in favor of something like `instUniformSpaceProd.comap (Unitization.addEquiv ùïú A)` here and below.
Having duplicate lemmas in a `simp only` feels like a typo?

```suggestion
theorem lipschitzWith_addEquiv :
    LipschitzWith 2 (Unitization.addEquiv ùïú A) := by
  rw [‚Üê Real.toNNReal_ofNat]
```

```suggestion
        .symm <| (isometry_mul ùïú A).norm_map_of_map_zero (map_zero _) _
```

```suggestion
  ¬∑ nontriviality A
```
I agree with your comment :smile:
This should probably move to an earlier file. Also I'm not sure about the name, does `lmul` stand for "left multiplication" or "linear multiplication"?

I intend for it to mean "continuous linear" because [ContinuousLinearMap.mulLeftRight](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/NormedSpace/OperatorNorm.html#ContinuousLinearMap.mulLeftRight) used to be called `continuous_linear_map.lmul_left_right`, for instance. We also have [NonUnitalAlgHom.lmul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Algebra/Bilinear.html#NonUnitalAlgHom.lmul), which I will mention in the docstring.
moved to `OperatorNorm` file, immediately after `ContinuousLinearMap.mul`

```suggestion
equal to the pullback of `instUniformSpaceProd` along `Unitization.addEquiv` (this is essentially
```

```suggestion
/-- Given `(k, a) : Unitization ùïú A`, the second coordinate of `Unitization.splitMul (k, a)` is
```

```suggestion
the natural representation of `Unitization ùïú A` on `A` given by multiplication on the left `A ‚ÜíL[ùïú] A`;
```
Is that what you wanted to write?

I think you could use [Topology.¬´termùì§[_]¬ª](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/UniformSpace/Basic.html#Topology.%C2%ABterm%F0%9D%93%A4[_]%C2%BB) to make this line a bit more readable
I thought that existed but it didn't work because I didn't have that scope open. Grrr... Why is it in the Topology namespace?
It shouldn't, unless we decide to put all uniformity notations in `Topology`, that would make sense too.

```suggestion
-- todo: why does Lean need these instances explictly?
```

I didn't understand it either, so let's just keep it as a TODO for now.
Could you make that a separate lemma? That way we can access the topology and uniform structure without actually unfolding it.
I'm surprised this is non-computable!
Hmmm... it's not. But I think I added it there originally because some IR check failed. It no longer seems to be complaining though, so I've removed `noncomputable`.
Can you move this to `Algebra/Algebra/Unitization.lean`?

To me this reads more clearly as
```suggestion
Given a not-necessarily-unital normed `ùïú`-algebra `A`, it is frequently of interest to equip its
```
but feel free to ignore

I think the parens are misplaced here:
```suggestion
on `A` is *regular* (i.e., `ContinuousLinearMap.mul` is an isometry), there is another natural
```
Nit: would be nice to have the nnnorm version too; and maybe dist and nndist lemmas
I think I did what you wanted, but let me know if not.
